channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Taming Pod::Weaver
item.description: It is Yanick Champoux story time again. This is such a great counter example of the other blog post, I read today. That rant about the lack of documentation. This is a solution. I love the way Yanick writes. I wish, I would understand more of it. No! I wish I could write like that.

item.title: Why Perl?
item.description: The Perl Weekly readers probably don't need any convincing as to why use Perl but this article by John Napiorkowski can be a good tool when you talk to others about the language.

item.title: Corelist and Perlbrew - 2 Perl command line tools for remote Perl work
item.description: Tyler Slijboom asks: Will this script run under the Perl version available to the customer? and then uses the above two tools to give an answer.

item.title: Yet another taint mode reminder
item.description: For improved security of your Perl application David Golden (dagolden) suggest the use of the (IMHO) mostly neglected taint mode of Perl.

item.title: Test::DBIx::Class
item.description: Wolfgang Kinkeldei too complains about documentation (this is the 3rd I read tonight) but he actually complains that there is too much of it ... so he provides a simple example on how to use the Test::DBIx::Class module.

item.title: The inevitable Tie::CHI
item.description: Caching a hash. Jonathan Swartz, the author of Mason and CHI shows how 'tie' can provide a very simple interface to a cache.

item.title: Pagination has become kids play with Dancer ...
item.description: Mohammad S Anwar is new on blogs.perl.org and this is his second very useful blog. This time he takes us through the way he used Template::Plugin::Pagination to divide up a result set to several pages of results.

item.title: Querying ElasticSearch from VIM
item.description: It is a bit unclear to me why did Ovid give this title while it seems the interesting part of his blog entry was the Perl script that highlights the character where a json file has a syntax error. The funny thing is that the Perl Weekly is based on a JSON file and I am writing it in Padre. So I already wanted to write a plugin to do syntax checking of JSON files. Now I can just take what Ovid wrote.
